title-group.article-title: Novel optically active poly(amide-thioester-imide)s containing l-α-amino acids and thiadiazol anticorrosion group
title-group.subtitle: Production and characterization

article-meta.aff: 1Organic Polymer Chemistry Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan, Islamic Republic of Iran
2Nanotechnology and Advanced Materials Institute, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan, Islamic Republic of Iran.

abstract.p: Here, for the first time, we report the synthesis of a new class of optically active polymers, poly(amide-thioester-imide)s (PATEI)s, containing flexible and anticorrosion linkages. Step growth polymerization of a novel diamine with diacids containing amino acid and trimellitylimide groups in tetrabutylammonium bromide, in the molten state, which acts as a molten ionic salt medium, was carried out. The obtained polymeric materials were of the nanoscale size and were assembled by filamentary particles as shown by field-emission scanning electron microscopy micrographs, which were distributed uniformly and randomly, with an average nanosize diameter of about 40 nm. The polymeric samples were readily soluble in a variety of common organic solvents and formed low-colored and flexible thin films via solution casting. The values of absorption edge wavelength (λ0) were determined by ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy, and all of the resulting PATEI films exhibited high-optical transparency. According to x-ray diffraction patterns, all the PATEIs were amorphous. The structure of PATEIs were also characterized by Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy, Proton-nuclear magnetic resonance, elemental, and thermogravimetric analysis techniques. The effect of ultrasound on the morphology of polymers was also investigated. This study confirmed that the size of polymer particles decreased and there was a change in their morphology.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: There is great interest in ionic liquids (ILs) as alternative materials for replacing conventional solvents used in some chemical applications and in a wide range of other uses. This is due to their significant differences in physical and chemical properties compared to the conventional solvents.1 The potential of ILs to act as solvents and catalysts for a broad range of chemical processes is attracting extensive attention from industry and academia, as they exhibit significant environmental and process benefits. ILs have been referred to as design solvents, which can be designed to optimize a variety of chemical synthesis of interest.2 Low vapor pressure (stable in high vacuum), excellent thermal stability, high viscosity, good conductivity, wide interval of hydrophilic–hydrophobic balance, good dissolution properties with many organic and inorganic compounds as well as polymers, not toxic, low flammability, and recyclability are the significant properties of these green materials.3–5 ILs containing tetraalkyl ammonium salts have been deeply investigated and availed in many branches of chemistry for many years. These ionic salts are not only used as reaction solvents but also exhibit catalytic properties.6–8 In the case of molten tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB), high solubility in water and polar organic solvents make it suitable as a reaction catalyst and medium in several types of chemical reactions as well as in polymer synthesis.9–12 Utilization of this property enables recovery and reuse of it, after extracting the product. This can help to reduce the waste of traditional solvents that are rarely reused.

In the past few decades, many studies concerned with the synthesis and characterization of optically active polymers have been carried out, because of their chiroptical and stereospecific properties.13 The optical activity of macromolecules is of particular importance in determining the nature of their interactions with living systems. One of the reasons for this may be ascribed to the chiral nature of the living systems. The most important application of chiral polymers is the enantiomeric separation in chromatography methods or chiral media for asymmetric synthesis.14–16 In the polycondensation reactions, we use amino acids as the chiral-inducting agents. Amino acid containing polymers are likely to possess crystallinity with the ability to form higher ordered structures that exhibit enhanced solubility characteristics.17

It is found that organic compounds bearing heteroatoms with high-electron density, such as sulfur, phosphor, nitrogen, oxygen or those containing multiple bonds, have anticorrosive behavior.18,19 The compounds contain both nitrogen and sulfur in their molecular structure, exhibiting greater inhibition compared with those containing only one of these elements.20–23 Among many heterocyclic corrosion inhibitors, 2-amino-5-mercapto-1,3,4-thiadiazole (AMT) was tested in many cases. For example, it was selected as a corrosion inhibitor in the conservation of bronze because of its ability to form insoluble complexes with copper I and II ions in the copper alloy and its corrosion products. It is believed to form a thin polymeric complex layer over the metal surface.24,25 However, few studies have focused on the production of polymer with AMT-linked groups for the matrix polymer itself.

In this study, we report a convenient, cost-effective, and environmentally benign green chemical method for the synthesis of new chiral poly(amide-thioester-imide)s (PATEI)s containing anticorrosive AMT moiety in the main chain from condensation of a novel aromatic diamine with several chiral imide-ring performed diacids under safe conditions. The characterization of the monomers and polymers such as Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) and proton-nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectroscopy, elemental, and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), optical, and physical properties are also investigated.

sec.title: Starting materials
sec.p: Commercially available AMT, 4-aminobenzoyl chloride, trimellitic anhydride, natural amino acids, glacial acetic acid, TBAB, and triphenyl phosphite (TPP) were used as received without further purification. These chemicals were purchased from Fluka Chemical Co. (Switzerland), Aldrich Chemical Co. (Milwaukee, Wisconsin, USA), Riedel-deHaen AG (Germany), and Merck Chemical Co. (Germany). N,N′-Dimethylacetamide (DMAc) (d = 0.94 g cm−3 at 20ºC) and N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF) (d = 0.94 g cm−3 at 20ºC) were distilled over barium oxide under reduced pressure prior to use.

sec.title: Measurements
sec.p: Melting points of the monomers were measured on a melting point apparatus (Gallenhamp, England) without correction.

1H and carbon-nuclear magnetic resonance (13C NMR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker (Germany) Avance 500 instrument at room temperature (RT) in dimethylsulfoxide-d6 (DMSO-d6). Multiplicities of proton resonance were designated as singlet (s), doublet (d), triplet (t), and multiplet (m). 13C spectrum is broadband proton decoupled. The chemical shifts were reported in ppm with respect to the references and were stated relative to external tetramethylsilane for 1H and 13C NMR.

FTIR spectra were recorded on a spectrophotometer (Jasco 680, Japan). The spectra of solids were obtained using KBr pellets. The vibrational transition frequencies are reported in wave numbers (cm−1). Band intensities are assigned as weak (w), medium (m), strong (s), and broad (br).

Elemental analysis was performed in an Elementar Analysensysteme GmbH, Germany. Ultraviolet maximum wavelength (λmax) values were determined with an ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) spectrophotometer, JASCO, V-570 in DMAc, at a concentration of 10−5 mol L−1 at RT.

Inherent viscosities were measured using a Cannon Fenske Routine Viscometer (Germany) at the concentration of 0.5 g/dL in DMF at 25°C. Optical specific rotations were measured at a concentration of 0.5 g/dL in DMF at 25°C using a quartz cell (1.0 cm) with a Jasco Polarimeter (JASCO Co., Ltd., Japan).
TGA is performed with a STA503 win TA (Bahr-Thermoanalyse GmbH, Hüllhorst, Germany) at a heating rate of 10°C min−1 from 25 to 800°C under nitrogen atmosphere.

The x-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of polymers were recorded using an XRD diffractometer (Bruker, D8ADVANCE, Germany) with a copper target at 40 kV and 35 mA and Cu Kα λ = 1.54 Å in the range of 0 to 80 at a speed of 0.05 min−1.

The morphology of the polymers was observed by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) (HITACHI S-4160, Japan). The effect of ultrasound energy on the size of polymer particles was investigated by MISONIX ultrasonic liquid processors, XL-2000 SERIES, USA. Ultrasound was a wave of frequency 2.25 × 104 Hz and power 100 W.

sec.title: Monomer synthesis procedure
sec.p: Synthesis of S-5-amino-1,3,4-thiadiazol-2-yl 4-aminobenzothioate. The typical synthesis procedure of the novel diamine compound 3 was given according to the strategy outline shown in Figure 1.

Into a 25-mL round-bottom flask, 0.50 g (3.75 × 10−3 mol) of AMT was suspended in a 15 mL of a 0.1 M NaOH solution under stirring at RT. After 10 min, the solution was cooled to 0°C in an ice bath and 0.58 g of 4-aminobenzoyl chloride (3.75 × 10−3 mol) was added to the mixture with vigorous stirring, and the reaction was continued for 6 h at 0°C. The reaction was carried out under nitrogen atmosphere. On completion of the reaction, the solution was neutralized, and a precipitate was formed slowly. It was washed with water and crystallized with a suitable solvent and the precipitated brown crystals were isolated. Purity of product was ascertained by thin-layer chromatography with a suitable solvent (yield = 76.2%, m.p. 252-254ºC). FTIR (KBr cm−1): 3,441 (s), 3,108 (s), 2,926 (m), 1,700 (s), 1,675 (s), 1,593 (s), 1,478 (s), 1,430 (s), 1,373 (m), 1,317 (m), 1,105 (m), 877 (m), 833 (s), 799 (m), 724 (s). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ; 5.26 (s, 2H, NH2), 6.507–6.527 (d, 2H, Ar–H, J = 8.12 Hz), 6.93 (s, 2H, NH2), 7.495–7.514 (d, 2H, Ar–H, J = 7.68 Hz). 13C NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 183.86 (C, C=O), 164.36 (C, Ar), 152.55 (CH, Ar), 149.93 (C, Ar), 136.63 (CH, Ar), 129.93 (C, Ar), 123.68 (CH, Ar) ppm. Elemental analysis: calculated for C9H8N4OS2: C, 42.84%; H, 3.20%, N, 22.21%; S, 25.42%; found: C, 42.92%; H, 3.19%; N, 22.13%; S, 25.20%.

Synthesis of N-trimellitylimido-L-α-amino acids. Optically active diacid monomers (6a-6d) such as N-trimellitylimido-L-leucine,26 N-trimellitylimido-L-isoleucine,27 N-trimellitylimido-S-valine,28 and N-trimellitylimido-L-alanine29 were prepared according to previous works (Figure 2).

Polymerization. The one-step polycondensation reaction of equimolecular amounts of diamine 3 and diacids (6a-6d), using molten TBAB as a reaction medium and TPP as a homogenizer, gave the PATEIs. A typical experimental procedure for polymerization reaction is given as follow: a mixture of aromatic diacid 6a (0.100 g, 3.27 × 10−4 mol), diamine 3 (0.082 g, 3.27 × 10−4 mol), and TBAB (0.420 g, 1.31 × 10−3 mol) was ground until a powder was formed. After the mixture was completely ground, it was transferred into a 25-mL, round-bottom flask and then 0.34 mL (1.31 × 10−3 mol) of TPP was added and the mixture was heated until a homogeneous solution was formed. Then the solution was stirred for 12 h at 120°C, and the viscous solution was precipitated in 15 mL of methanol. The yellow solid was filtered off and dried to obtain 0.145 g (85%) of PATEI7a. The other PATEIs, PATEIs 7b and 7d were prepared by a similar procedure.

sec.title: Synthesis and structural characterization of monomers
sec.p: Diacid monomers were synthesized by the condensation reaction of an equimolar amount of trimellitic anhydride (4) and different amino acids (L-leucine, L-isoleucine, S-valine, and L-alanine (5a-5d)) in reflux acetic acid solution (Figure 2).26–29 Diamine monomer 3 was synthesized using a single-step reaction of equimolecular amounts of AMT (1) and 4-aminobenzoyl chloride (2) (Figure 1). The structure of the diamine 3 was identified by elemental analysis, FTIR, 1H NMR, and 13C NMR spectroscopy. Infrared spectrum of diamine 3 showed strong band of absorption at 1700 cm−1 which was assigned to thioester group. The absorption peak of amine functions ia obvious at around 3,341 cm−1. The 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra (400 MHz) of diamine 3 were also confirmed by the structure for diamine 3. The 1H NMR spectrum (Figure 3, bottom) of diamine 3 presented aromatic proton signals in the range of 6.50–7.51 ppm, as doublet, which were easily attributable and compatible with the proposed structure. In this spectrum, the protons for the amine groups are observed at 5.26 and 6.93 ppm, respectively. The 13C NMR spectrum (Figure 3, top) of diamine compound 3 exhibited six peaks of various absorptions for aromatic carbons and a peak for carbonyl of thioester group. In this spectrum, the aforementioned carbons were observed at about δ 183.86 (C, C=O), 164.36 (C, Ar), 152.55 (CH, Ar), 149.93 (C, Ar), 136.63 (CH, Ar), 129.93 (C, Ar), and 123.68 (CH, Ar) ppm.

caption.p: 13C NMR (top) and 1H NMR (bottom) (400 MHz) spectra of diamine 3 in DMSO-d6 at RT. 1H NMR: proton nuclear magnetic resonance; 13C NMR: carbon-nuclear magnetic resonance; RT: room temperature; DMSO-d6; dimethylsulphoxide-d6.

sec.title: Synthesis of PATEIs
sec.p: There is a great need to develop new methodologies for manipulation of different functionalities in polymerization reactions using green chemistry that could replace the conventional solvents and provide better conditions. In contrast to common organic solvents, ILs do not produce volatile organic compounds due to their low vapor pressure. Also, ILs are inexpensive to prepare and easy to recycle. Therefore, in our continuing effort to develop easily processable high-performance polymers which have good solubility and thermal stability, we eliminated common organic solvents such as N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), DMAc, and DMF and performed the polymerization reaction under safe conditions to report a simple, green, and efficient method for the synthesis of several optically active PATEIs via the direct polycondensation reaction of several natural amino acid containing diacids (6a-6d) with an aromatic diamine (3) containing anticorrosion AMT moiety in molten TBAB in the presence of TPP (Figure 2). This molten ionic salt was selected because it proved to be the most valuable among those employed in our recent studies.11,12 Runs in molten salt were carried out by thermal heating technique. The entire polycondensation reaction readily proceeds in a homogeneous solution and after work-up tough and stringy precipitates was formed. The syntheses and some physical properties of these new PATEIs 7a-7d are given in Table 1. All the polymers were obtained in high yields (85–90%), and the inherent viscosities were in the range of 0.43–0.48 dL/g, which were measured in DMF solutions. The resulting polymers also showed a yellow color. All were optically active, because they have a chiral center from amino acid residue in their pendant groups. The structure of the PATIEs was confirmed by FTIR and 1H NMR spectroscopy and elemental analysis technique.

sec.title: Structural identification
sec.p: The formation of PATEIs was confirmed using FTIR spectroscopy. Strong absorption bands are observed at 1775–1776 cm−1. These are attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the imide carbonyl groups. The bands of C–N bond stretching and ring deformation appear at 1381–1383 cm−1. Strong bands of absorption characteristic of the newly formed amide linkage appeared at around 3,419–3,447 cm−1 assigned to N–H stretching vibration, at 1,664–1,668 cm−1 attributed to C=O stretching vibration, and at 1,576 cm−1 due to the N–H bending vibration. The absorption band at around 3,117 cm−1 was attributed to =CH aromatic linkage. Some of the structures polymers were also confirmed with 1H NMR spectroscopy. Figure 4 shows the 1H NMR (400 MHz) spectrum of PATEI7b. In the 1H NMR spectrum of this polymer, appearances of the N–H protons of amide groups at 10.03 and 10.61 ppm, as two singlet peaks, indicate the presence of amide groups in the polymer’s main chain. The resonance of aromatic protons appeared in the range of 6.35–8.48 ppm. The proton of the chiral center appeared as doublet at 4.58–4.60 ppm.

caption.p: 1H NMR (400 MHz) spectrum of PATEI7b in DMSO-d6 at RT. 1H NMR: proton nuclear magnetic resonance; PATEI: poly(amide-thioester-imide); RT: room temperature; DMSO-d6; dimethylsulphoxide-d6.

sec.title: Organosolubility
sec.p: There is an assembly of general rules for polymer solubility, based on experimental observations, from which interesting conclusions can be obtained. It is well known that the dissolution of polymers depends not only on their physical properties but also on their chemical structure, such as polarity, molecular weight, branching, crosslinking degree, and crystallinity. Conventional wholly aromatic PIs are insoluble in common organic solvents. The introduction of nonlinear flexible linkages and polar functional groups such as –CO–NH–, –CO–O–, and –CO–S– into the main chain or the side chain of aromatic polymers greatly enhances molecular mobility and provides better solubility. Therefore, in the case of these polymers, the introduction of amide, imide, and thioester functional groups in the polymer main chain can improve the solubility. The solubility of obtained PATEIs 7a-7d was investigated as 0.01 g of polymeric sample in 2 mL of solvent. All the synthesized polymers were soluble in organic solvents such as DMF, DMAc, DMSO, NMP, pyridine, and in H2SO4 at RT, and in phenolic solvents such as m-cresol, and insoluble in solvents such as methanol, ethanol, chloroform, methylene chloride, ethyl acetate, and water (Table 2).

caption.p: Solubilitya of the prepared polymers in common organic solvents.

sec.title: Thermostability
sec.p: The thermostability of the resulting PATEIs was evaluated by TGA under nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10°C min−1, and corresponding weight loss temperatures of 5 and 10% (Td5% and Td10%) were all determined from original TGA curves. All the aromatic PATEIs exhibited good thermal stability with insignificant weight loss up to 350°C in nitrogen. The Td5% and Td10% values of the PATEIs stayed within the range of 350–358°C and 376–394°C, respectively. The amount of carbonized residue (CR) (char yield) of these polymers in nitrogen atmosphere was up to 40% at 800°C. The high char yields of these polymers can be ascribed to their high-aromatic content. Obviously, the data from thermal analysis showed that these PATEIs have fairly high-thermal stability. Typical TGA curves of representative PATEIs 7b and 7c are shown in Figure 5 (bottom). In addition, the results obtained from these analyses are entirely tabulated in Table 3.

sec.title: Limiting oxygen index (LOI) – the self-extinguishing polymer
sec.p: The LOI is a measure of the percentage of oxygen to be present to support combustion of the material. The LOI value can be used to evaluate the flame retardancy of polymers. The percentage of oxygen in the air is around 21%, it is clear that all materials with an LOI lower than this level will burn easily, while those with a higher LOI will tend not to burn. Theoretically, CR can also be used as criteria for evaluating LOI of polymers. According to Van Krevelen equation,30 LOI = 17.5 + 0.4 CR, PATEIs 7b and 7c had LOI value of 35.9 and 35.1, respectively, which were calculated from their CR. From this equation, a higher CR will enhance flame retardancy. On the basis of the LOI values, such PATEIs can be used as self-extinguishing polymers.
There is also an interesting relationship between the LOI and heat of combustion according to Johnson equation:31LOI=8,000/ΔHcomb
where ΔHcomb is the specific heat of combustion in J/g. Therefore, in the case of these polymers (PATEIs 7b and 7c), ΔHcomb is 22.3 and 22.8, respectively.

sec.title: Film characteristics and optical properties
sec.p: All the prepared PATEIs are lightly colored, and they were also subjected to UV–vis spectrum. From the spectral results (Table 4), it has been confirmed that the presence of alkyl groups in the polymer backbone has eliminated the electronic polarization by breaking up the extended conjugation along the chain, which results in color. Apart from this, the incorporation of a bulky thiadiazole unit has also inhibited the chain-chain packing via the increased entropy mechanism. However, the small variations observed in the cutoff wavelength may be due to the nature of diamine and anhydride moieties present in the polymer backbone. These polymers exhibit strong UV–vis absorption bands at 273–274 nm in DMAc solution, which are peculiar to the combinations of n-π* and π-π* transitions resulting from the conjugated thioester group and AMT segment. On the other hand, to prepare a crack-free and homogeneous thin film, solutions of the polymers were prepared by dissolving 0.50 g of the samples in 5 mL of DMAc. These solutions were poured into an 8 cm glass petri dish, which was heated under vacuum at 90°C in a oven overnight, 100°C for 3 h, 120°C for 2 h, and 150°C for 1 h to slowly evaporate the solvent. By being soaked in distilled water, the flexible and transparent thin film with low-color intensity was self-stripped from the glass surface. The obtained films were then used to investigate the optical properties of the PATEIs. The plateau region of the light transmittance in the UV–vis spectra was extended to about 500 nm, indicating high degree of the films transparency.32 Moreover, the λ0 values (absorption edge or cutoff wavelength) of the resulting PATEIs were found to be in the range of 431–434 nm. Generally, the results obtained clearly show that the prepared thin films have low color intensity and high level of optical transparency in the UV–vis light region. Table 4 lists the characteristics of the resulting films and the values of absorption edge. Furthermore, Figure 6(a) and (b) shows molar absorptivity spectrum of representative PATEI7b solution and UV–vis transmission spectrum of the same polymer film.

sec.title: XRD studies
sec.p: The crystallinity of the resulting PATEIs was measured by XRD at RT with 2θ ranging from 10 to 80°. X-Ray diffractograms are shown in Figure 7. In general, the diffraction patterns were broad, which indicated that most of the mentioned PATEIs were essentially amorphous. The amorphous character is due to the presence of flexible –CO–S–, –CO–NH–, –CH2–, –C(CH3)2−, –CH3−, and imide groups in the chain, which prevents the chain-chain interaction leading to amorphous morphology.

caption.p: XRD patterns of PATEIs 7b and 7c. XRD: x-ray diffraction; PATEIs: poly(amide-thioester-imide)s.

sec.title: Morphological studies
sec.p: Morphological characterization of PATEIs was studied by FE-SEM. The respective FE-SEM images of PATEIs 7b and 7c are shown in Figure 8. As can be seen from these images, the average diameter of polymeric particles is about 40 nm and they distribute uniformly and randomly in a filamentary morphology.

caption.p: FE-SEM micrographs of PATEI7b (a and b) and PATEI7c (c and d). FE-SEM: field-emission scanning electron microscopy; PATEI: poly(amide-thioester-imide).

sec.p: It is well known that ultrasonic irradiation is a well-established method for particle size reduction in dispersions and emulsions as well as generation and application of nanosize materials, because of the potential in the deagglomeration and the reduction of primaries. As most nanomaterials are still fairly expensive, this aspect is of high importance for the commercialization of product formulations containing nanomaterials.33 Herein, powders of polymers have been subjected to irradiation with high-intensity ultrasound for 1 h while suspended in ethanol. The homogeneous suspension was placed in a 60°C oven overnight to evaporate most of the solvent. Then the semidried polymer powder was further dried in vacuo at 80°C for 8 h. The resulting images from FE-SEM confirmed that after ultrasonic irradiation the size of polymeric nanoparticles decreased (22–28 nm) and their morphology also changed (Figure 9).

caption.p: FE-SEM micrographs of PATEI7b (a and b) and PATEI7c (c and d) after ultrasonication of suspended polymer in ethanol.
FE-SEM: field-emission scanning electron microscopy; PATEI: poly(amide-thioester-imide).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A new diamine, S-5-amino-1,3,4-thiadiazol-2-yl 4-aminobenzothioate, bearing thioester linkage and anticorrosion AMT group, was successfully synthesized in a one-step procedure. Next, a series of aromatic PATEIs have been readily prepared from diamine and various natural amino acids containing diacids via direct polycondensation method in molten TBAB salt. Incorporating the thioester, amide, and imide groups along the asymmetrically oriented chains could increase the organosolubility of the polymers. Moreover, local macromolecular twisting caused by high association between bulky groups must be added to molecular asymmetry that leads to the disrupting the copolanarity of aromatic rings. The introduction of amide, imide, and thioester groups into the polymer chains could change their alignment and so prevent effective charge-transfer complex formation. Accordingly, all the polymeric low colored thin films were significantly flexible and showed high-optical transparency in the UV–vis light region. The surface of the thin films obtained from these polymers is smooth, without pinholes. The obtained polymers have AMT group in their main chain and they can be classified under anticorrosion materials. In summary, these novel PATEIs displayed excellent organosolubility, good film-forming capability, and reasonable thermal stability and are suitable for thermoforming processing, and they have potential applications such as high-powered materials, processable high-performance engineering plastics, constructing chiral media for asymmetric synthesis, and chiral stationary phases for resolution of racemic mixtures by chromatographic techniques.
